Poster

PSTR413.16 / PP8 - Integrating hippocampal replay, prefrontal schemas, through the reinforcement learning of sequences

Keiland W Cooper, Hamed Poursiami, Zoey Yang, Maryam Parsa, Norbert J Fortin

November 19, 2025, 8:00 AM - 12:00 PM

View Abstract

Non-spatial sequence memory is crucial for navigating complex environments and making informed decisions. The hippocampus and prefrontal cortex are pivotal in these processes, with the hippocampus traditionally implicated in episodic memory and spatial navigation, and the prefrontal cortex in executive functions and flexible use of schemas. We recorded hippocampal activity as rats remembered an extended sequence of nonspatial events unfolding over several seconds, as in daily life episodes in humans. We found that the hippocampus's exhibits non-spatial sequence reactivation of past, present, and future odors during active sampling, as well as signs of awake replay of event sequences, suggesting its involvement in flexible processing and consolidation of sequences of events. Concurrently we find evidence of the prefrontal cortex's utilizing ordinal schemas, structured knowledge representations that facilitate efficient sequence learning and prediction. We bridge these data by proposing an innovative computational model that connects hippocampal non-spatial replay with prefrontal action selection and schemas utilizing a reinforcement learning (RL) framework. This model, grounded in the anatomical circuitry of the hippocampus, was trained on a novel sequence task framework. We propose HiCoS (Hierarchical Contextual Sequences), a structured RL environment grounded in neuroscientific studies on event-sequence learning and context-driven decision-making. Taken together, this framework helps demonstrate how hippocampal replay mechanisms can drive the formation and flexible use of predictive schemas in the prefrontal cortex, thereby enabling flexible and adaptive behavioral strategies in complex, non-spatial environments.

Key Literature

A scalable reinforcement learning framework inspired by hippocampal memory mechanisms for efficient contextual and sequential decision making

Hamed Poursiami, Ayana Moshruba, Keiland W Cooper, Derek Gobin, Md Abdullah-Al Kaiser, Ankur Singh, Rouhan Noor, Babak Shahbaba, Akhilesh Jaiswal, Norbert J Fortin, Maryam Parsa. Scientific Reports, 2025

Hippocampal ensembles represent sequential relationships among an extended sequence of nonspatial events

Babak Shahbaba, Lingge Li, Forest Agostinelli, Mansi Saraf, Keiland W Cooper, Derenik Haghverdian, Gabriel A Elias, Pierre Baldi, Norbert J Fortin. Nature Communications, 2022

Biography

Keiland Cooper is a cognitive scientist, neuroscientist, and AI researcher broadly interested in the dynamics of intelligent systems. He has worked on multiple research projects ranging from how the brain learns and creates memories, to novel artificial intelligence tools, to the neurological impacts of COVID-19. A first-generation college student, Keiland is affiliated with the department of Neurobiology and Behavior, at the University of California, Irvine. He is also the co-founder of ContinualAI, one of the largest global artificial intelligence research non-profits spanning academia and industry. Keiland is a National Science Foundation Fellow and UCI Pedagogical Fellow. Passionate about science communication, Keiland hosts multiple discussions about neuroscience and AI, to audiences ranging from students, the government, or the media.
